coredata.dc:title: The effects of lithium salt and solvent on lithium metal anode performance
coredata.dc:creator: Li, Yulan
Yang, Zhongfa
Wu, Zhenrui
Li, Jie
Zou, Jian
Jiang, Cheng
Yang, Jingyi
Wang, Liping
Niu, Xiaobin
coredata.dc:description: In this study, the effects of lithium salts (i.e. LiPF6, LiClO4 and LiN(SO2CF3)2) and solvents (i.e. carbonate and ether type) on the Li metal anode electrochemical performance are systematically studied. It is found that LiN(SO2CF3)2, denoted as LiTFSI, in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) as electrolyte offers the best performance with a cycle life of 1100 h under the capacity of 2 mAh/cm2 and current density of 2 mA/cm2. Lithium stripping/plating produces porous loose lithium powders rather than dendrites. Both lithium salts and solvents have influences on the lithium powder nucleation and growth. In the LiTFSI-DOL/DME system, lithium metal after stripping/plating has a relative flat and dense surface, which concomitantly brings in a low charge transfer resistance, low solid electrolyte interphase resistance, and elongated cycle life. A high Li+ transference number and a high Li+-solvent interaction force are beneficial to an even Li+ flux and a stable Li-electrolyte interface. This study sheds light on the importance of electrolytes for high performance lithium metal anodes.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Cycling performance of Li-Li symmetric cell in different lithium salts with carbonate-based solvents with a capacity of 0.5 mAh/cm2 at a current density of 0.5 mA/cm2. (b) Enlarged galvanostatic charge-discharge curves at different cycles based on a. The cells are rested for 6 h at the very beginning for a better permeation between the electrolytes and the metal. (c) Rate performance of the Li-Li cell with different current rates with the 1 hour-charging and 1 hour-discharging per cycle.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) evolutions and ZView software fitting results as a function of cycling number. (a, b) LiClO4-EC/DMC system, (c, d) LiPF6-EC/DMC system, (e, f) LiTFSI-EC/DMC system.

Top view and cross-section view SEM images of (a, b) pristine Li metal, (c, d) Li metal in LiClO4-EC/DMC, (e, f) Li metal in LiPF6-EC/DMC, (g, h) LiTFSI-EC/DMC after 100 cycles with a capacity of 1 mAh/cm2 at a current density of 1 mA/cm2.

(a) Cycling performance of Li-Li symmetric cells in 1 M LiTFSI salt with different electrolyte solvents (EC/DMC and DOL/DME) with a capacity of 2 mAh/cm2 at a current density of 2 mA/cm2. (b) Enlarged galvanostatic charge-discharge curves at different cycles based on a. (c–e) EIS response at different cycles for the LiTFSI-DOL/DME system.

Top view and cross section view SEM images of (a, b) lithium metal after 50 cycles in carbonate-based electrolyte, (c, d) lithium metal after 50 cycles in ether-based electrolyte. Both are controlled with a capacity of 2 mAh/cm2 under a current rate of 2 mA/cm2.

head.ce:title: The effects of lithium salt and solvent on lithium metal anode performance

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In this study, the effects of lithium salts (i.e. LiPF6, LiClO4 and LiN(SO2CF3)2) and solvents (i.e. carbonate and ether type) on the Li metal anode electrochemical performance are systematically studied. It is found that LiN(SO2CF3)2, denoted as LiTFSI, in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) as electrolyte offers the best performance with a cycle life of 1100 h under the capacity of 2 mAh/cm2 and current density of 2 mA/cm2. Lithium stripping/plating produces porous loose lithium powders rather than dendrites. Both lithium salts and solvents have influences on the lithium powder nucleation and growth. In the LiTFSI-DOL/DME system, lithium metal after stripping/plating has a relative flat and dense surface, which concomitantly brings in a low charge transfer resistance, low solid electrolyte interphase resistance, and elongated cycle life. A high Li+ transference number and a high Li+-solvent interaction force are beneficial to an even Li+ flux and a stable Li-electrolyte interface. This study sheds light on the importance of electrolytes for high performance lithium metal anodes.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium metal-based batteries, e.g. Li-sulfur, Li-oxygen, Li-layer cathodes Li[LixMnyNizCo1−x−y−z]O2, offering energy densities of >500 Wh/kg are good candidates for applications in the electrical vehicles [1–3]. There are three main challenges for the lithium metal anodes. One is that Li metal is highly chemical active, which can easily have spontaneous reactions with the ambient air and conventional non-aqueous liquid electrolytes to form a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI). Since the formed SEI layer is normally heterogeneous and anisotropic, it can lead an inhomogeneous lithium nucleation and growth. Meanwhile, the exposed newly formed lithium can consume electrolytes resulting in a low Coulombic efficiency and a short cycling life. Formation of a stable SEI layer via physical coating and in-situ chemical reaction as well as choosing stable electrolytes such as solid-state electrolytes are common ways to diminish the parasitic reactions [4–7]. One is that it has a huge volume expansion as lithium is a host-free metal (1 mAh/cm2 metal corresponding to a thickness of 4.8 μm). Such an expansion can bring in a high contact resistance especially in the solid-state battery system. Meanwhile, the aforementioned artificial surface coating layer can normally be exfoliated after several cycles. Introducing 3D current collectors such as carbon sponges, Cu nano-rods, Ni foams have been demonstrated effective routes [8–10]. Another is that the Li+ flux, highly affected by the lithium metal surface state and the lithium ion diffusion rate [11], is usually uneven, which leads to a preference of island-by-island growth instead of film-by-film growth. Increasing the lithium ion concentration, selecting proper electrolyte additives, and decreasing the applied current density have been proved effective strategies in enhancing lithium metal anode life [6].

Electrolytes consisting of various lithium salts and solvents have important influences on the lithium metal nucleation and growth in the lithium plating process. According to the sand's equation

, mossy morphology rather than dendrites tend to form a high apparent lithium ion diffusion rate (D
app ), high Li+ concentration (C 0), low operation current density (J), and high anion transference number (t
a ) [12, 13]. Suo and coauthors demonstrated a superior Li metal anode cyclic performance in 7 M LiTFSI-DOL/DME electrolyte [14]. Lu et al. fabricated a Li-containing polymer electrolyte membrane with high t Li+ ≈ 0.84 that exhibited a uniform lithium electro-deposition [15]. Qian et al. reported a Li-Li cell can cycle >6000 cycles under a current density 10 mA/cm2 in 4 M LiTFSI and 1,2-dimethoxyethane as electrolyte, ascribed to a high Li+ concentration and a high solvent-Li+ solvation ability [16].

In this work, we are trying to make a fundamental study on the effect of electrolytes in terms of lithium salts and solvents on the performance of lithium metal anodes. The LiPF6, LiClO4, and LiTFSI are the most commonly used lithium salts. The carbonate EC/DMC and ether DOL/DME are also the most popular solvents. Their concentrations are set to be 1 M. The cycling performance under different current densities, resistance evolution including charge transfer resistance (Rct) and surface film resistance (Rf), as well as the lithium metal morphology variation during plating and stripping are systematically studied. It is found that the LiTFSI has the best compatibility with DOL/DME electrolyte, in which the Li-Li cell presents the best cycling life and rate performance, smallest Rct and stable Rf, and a smallest lithium metal morphology change after cycling. Interestingly, the dense lithium metal foil with thickness of 160 μm becomes a porous lithium powders on surface with a thickness about 300 μm after only 50 stripping/electroplating cycles. A higher Li+ transference number and a higher Li+-solvent interaction are suspected to guarantee a more even Li+ flux and a stable Li-electrolyte interface.

Three different lithium salts, LiPF6 (>97%, Shanghai Aladdin), LiClO4 (>98%, Shanghai Aladdin), and LiTFSI (>99%, Shanghai Aladdin), were separately dissolved in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (EC/DMC, volume ratio of 1:1, purchased from Guotai Huarong Co. Ltd.) to produce 1 mol/L carbonate electrolyte. The ether-based electrolyte 1 M LiTFSI-DOL/DME (Guotai Huarong Co. Ltd.) was used as received. The lithium metal foil has a thickness of 160 μm. Symmetric Li-Li 2032-type coin cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box. The electrolytes were fixed to be 40 μL per cell.

Galvanostatic charge-discharge measurements were performed on instrument CT2001A (LANHE Co., China). An electrochemical workstation model CHI660B (Chen-Hua Instruments Inc.) was used to carry out electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements. A 5 mV bias was applied on the cells with the frequency ranging from 10−2 to 105 Hz. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI NanoSEM 430) was employed for morphology characterizations.

Fig. 1 shows the Li-Li cell cycling performance under galvanostatic stripping/plating process in different lithium salts electrolytes. All these three Li-Li cells have a “horn” type charge-discharge curves. They undergo an activation process with mild decreasing polarizations at the initial cycles followed by dramatic increasing polarizations. The cells are most probably terminated by running out of the electrolyte. It demonstrates that LiTFSI-EC/DMC electrolyte type cell gives the best cycling life for 650 cycles (namely 1300 h) under a current density of 0.5 mA/cm2 with a capacity of 0.5 mAh/cm2. With the increase of current density, all cycling time rapidly decreases as shown in Fig. 1c. For LiClO4-EC/DMC cell, it has a calendar life of 750 h under 0.5 mA/cm2, 370 h under 1 mA/cm2, and 150 h under 2 mA/cm2. As for the LiPF6-EC/DMC cell, the current density 0.5 mA/cm2, 1.0 mA/cm2, 2.0 mA/cm2 correspond to a cycling life of 820 h, 400 h, 150 h respectively. Regarding the LiTFSI-EC/DMC system, it has a cycle life of 1300 h, 550 h, 180 h at the current density 0.5 mA/cm2, 1.0 mA/cm2, 2.0 mA/cm2, respectively. Obviously, the LiTFSI salts guarantee the best cycling and rate performance. We know that TFSI− anion is larger than ClO4 − and PF6 − and the Li+ transference number in 1 M LiClO4, LiPF6, LiTFSI are 0.22, 0.25, and 0.85, respectively [14, 17, 18]. Based on the sand's equation, a high Li+ transference number brings in long sand's time, which indicates a later lithium dendrites formation and a good cycling performance.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is a powerful technique that can identify the internal resistance (Rs), the solid electrolyte interphase film resistance (Rf) and the charge transfer resistance (Rct) after a proper fitting circuit with ZView software. Fig. 2 shows the resistance evolutions as a function of cycling number. Consistent with the charge-discharge curves, all the Li-Li cells have an activation process with decreasing Rct in the first ten cycles followed by Rct increments. The internal resistance for the typical cells is <20 Ω. They have a small variation during cycling. Regarding the Rct and Rf, they are larger than the Rs with typical values of 50–300 Ω. We have found a clue that a rapid increase in the overall resistance (Rs + Rf + Rct), for example in the LiClO4-EC/DMC cell (Fig. 2a–b), makes an early death. The cell consisting of LiPF6-EC/DMC electrolyte has a large Rf at the very beginning, which is possible formation of LiF insulator (Fig. 2c–d). The LiTFSI-EC/DMC cell is the most stable one, as the Rct and Rf has no tendency of growth, even after 150 cycles, suggesting a good performance (Fig. 2e–f).

It would be meaningful to explore the lithium morphology change after stripping and electroplating. The pristine Li film has a flat surface (Fig. 3a) and is compact with a thickness of 160 μm evidenced from the cross-section SEM image (Fig. 3b). After 100 cycles with a capacity of 1 mAh/cm2 at a current density of 1 mA/cm2, their top-view and cross-view morphology are harvested. Note that the pristine lithium with a thickness of 160 μm makes a capacity of 32 mAh/cm2, which means that it is much higher than the demanded capacity 1 mAh/cm2 (to a thickness of 4.8 μm). After cycling, lithium metal film becomes porous and rough moss rather than dendrites (Fig. 3c–h). What is more, the newly formed lithium metal powders have cracks. More surprisingly, the films have a very high volume expansion after cycling. For the LiClO4-based, LiPF6-based, LiTFSI-based system, their thicknesses swell to 480 μm, 320 μm, and 265 μm, respectively. All these show that the Li metal prefers an island-by-island growth model as a consequence of uneven Li+ flux in the liquid electrolyte systems. A swell thickness illustrates that most of the loose powders have no electrochemical activity. Combined with the EIS study in Fig. 2, we infer that the loose powders with high surface area are prone to have parasitic reactions with the electrolytes to form SEI and consume electrolyte leading a low Coulombic efficiency and short cycle life, which embodies a high polarization in charge-discharge curves and increased Rct and Rf in EIS.

Besides the lithium salts, the solvents are also critical factors to the Li+ flux distribution. The most common solvents for lithium ion batteries are carbonates and ethers. Here we compare the electrochemical differences under the current density of 2 mA/cm2 in Li-Li cells with 1 M LiTFSI dissolved in different electrolytes, i.e. EC/DMC and DOL/DME. Fig. 4a reveals that the carbonate-based cell is dead very early within 300 h, while the ether-based cell can struggle 1100 h. Note that the theoretical Li+/Li voltage is 0 V. The charge-discharge curves in DOL/DME system show a much smaller polarization than the EC/DMC one (Fig. 4b). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is also used to investigate the resistance evolution as a function of cycling time. Similar as the carbonate-based cell, the ether-based cell also has an activation process. Its Rct and Rf are >200 Ω at the pristine state (Fig. 4c). While after one cycle, their Rct and Rf become very small. It is worth mentioning that there is almost no formation of SEI as the Rf is <20 Ω. In line with our previous study, the Rct is much smaller in the ether than that in the carbonate electrolyte system [19]. Park et al. reported that ether electrolytes have a lower reduction potential than the carbonates [20]. Moreover, DOL/DME solvents have a high electron donation number (N = 20) than EC/DMC (N = 16), which makes the Li+ more easily to coordinate the ether [21]. Moreover, according to the study of Aurbach et al., lithium metals reacting with ether produces flexible and highly Li+ conductive oligomers, which has good adhesions to the lithium metal [22]. In words, the ether-based electrolyte is more stable to form thin SEI and have a high charge transfer rate.

The lithium metal microstructures are detected via top-view and cross-view SEM (Fig. 5 ). Compared with Fig. 3g–h, the lithium metal surface is rougher and the lithium powders have larger particle sizes when the current rate increases to 2 mA/cm2. The Li metal particle distributions are less homogeneous limited by kinetics. On the other hand, the Li powders prefer to nuclear and grow in a dense flake shape films in the LiTFSI-DOL/DME system. Such a dense film can well explain its superior cycling performance, low Rct, and low Rf. It is suspected that the Li+ in the DOL/DME has a better diffusion rates to provide a layer-by-layer film growth mode.

In this study, the effects of lithium salts (i.e. LiClO4, LiPF6, and LiTFSI) and solvents (EC/DMC and DOL/DME) on the lithium metal anode performance are systematically studied. In the LiTFSI-DOL/DME electrolytes, lithium metal demonstrates the longest cycle life with 1100 h under a capacity of 2 mAh/cm2 and a current density of 2 mA/cm2. A higher Li+ transference number and a more stable solvent contribute to an even Li+ flux for a more homogeneous nucleation and growth accompanied with a smaller Rct and Rf. This study obeys the Sand's equation and addresses the importance of electrolytes. Inspired by this, searching stable electrolytes with high Li+ transference number, such as solid-state electrolyte, could be good options for high performance lithium metal anodes. Moreover, the huge lithium metal volume expansion during stripping/plating points out the necessity of constructing 3D current frameworks to accommodate newly formed Li.
